title: How YOU could end up on the US no-fly list
text:
97 shares 182
View
comments
Be careful what you tweet - because it could ruin your holiday plans.
A controversial posting can result in being banned from entering or leaving the US on a plane, according to a news website.
It's one of several ways individuals can end up on the 'no-fly' list, it revealed, with many not even realising that they're on it.
The no-fly list applies to those fliers who are banned from commercially flying in or out of a country, and many do not even know they are on it
Previously remaining a secret from the public, a leaked document obtained by the Intercept discovered that as of August 2013, there were 47,000 individuals on the United States' list.
Many of the 800 Americans on it have contested the decision.
Last summer, a federal court ruled in favour of 13 people who said the government violated their constitutional rights to travel by placing them on the no-fly list.

Qatar Airways finally 'shamed' into relaxing controversial... The worst security guards in the world? Shocking photos show... Share this article Share 97 shares The outcome of the ruling forced the government to spell out the reasons why the plaintiffs were barred and to provide an opportunity to challenge the government finding.
Despite the cases, the government maintains that secrecy is key to the system so terrorists are not made aware they are being tracked.
Under legal pressure, however, the Obama administration will begin telling some suspected terrorists if and why they are on the list.
Here are seven possible routes to being grounded.
The government maintain that secrecy is key to the system so terrorists are not made aware they are being tracked but many have fought the right to know if they are featured
1. Being linked to terrorism activity
The Intercept leak not only listed the number on the list, but also explained the process behind names being added through terrorism activity.
People included on the list included those convicted of or arrested for acts of terrorism, assassins, bombers, hostage takers, associates of terror groups amongst others.
According to the document, issued by the National Counterterrorism Center, federal agencies can put someone forward for a government blacklist if 'an individual is known or suspected to be or has been knowingly engaged in conduct constituting, in preparation for, in aid of, or related to TERRORISM and/or TERRORIST ACTIVITIES.'
Earlier this year it was discovered that the Charlie Hebdo murderers, Cherif and Said Kouachi, were on a British no-fly list after they were linked to Al Qaeda terrorists in 2008.
The brothers had been identified as a potential terror threat and placed on the list in case they tried to enter the UK or transit through a British airport.
The brothers were killed in a shoot-out after hiding in an industrial unit, two days after the attack on the offices of the satirical magazine, which killed 12 people.
2. Drug use
In April last year, Nigella Lawson was banned from leaving Heathrow on a U.S-bound flight because she had admitted to taking drugs.
The 'Domestic Goddess' was forced to confess under oath during a trial that she had snorted cocaine seven times and smoked cannabis in front of her children.
Although Scotland Yard did not act over her confession, the U.S. authorities took a tougher stance.
Miss Lawson is thought to have tried to enter the U.S. by registering online for permission to travel and confirming she had not been arrested or convicted of offences including taking illegal drugs.
But the US can also decide to bar foreigners who have committed drugs offences without ever being charged. Would-be travellers can apply to have the ban lifted, but this can take months.
3. Travelling frequently to the wrong country
Certain trouble areas can cause questions to be asked, and frequent travel to these areas can be a reason for concern.
Airline industry analyst Robert Mann said to Yahoo Travel : 'If you travel frequently to countries that are known to be involved in terrorism or financial crimes, you do run the risk of having your travels alerted more carefully.'
4. Error on the form
Sometimes errors can occur - like the FBI ticking the wrong box on a form.
A former Stanford University student was mistakenly suspected as a terrorist and placed on the government's 'no-fly' list for nine years because an FBI agent checked the wrong box on her form.
Rahinah Ibrahim, 48, an architect and scholar, was finally allowed to return to the United States in 2014 after fighting to clear her name since 2005.
In January of that year, Ibrahim was arrested and detained for two hours at San Francisco Airport as she boarded a flight to her native Malaysia with her 14-year-old daughter.
Alsup said the reason for the initial mistake was that FBI special agent Kevin Kelly, who was investigating Ibrahim for reasons the government won't disclose, had 'misunderstood the directions' on a government form and 'checked the wrong boxes' â€” ignoring written instructions that she should not be placed on the no-fly list, according to The Chronicle.
Sometimes errors can occur, and this has been the case for a number of cases where the FBI have ticked the wrong box on a form
5. Having a similar name as someone on the list
In 2007, TV programme 60 Minutes researched and interviewed 12 individuals who shared names of people on the list.
These included people who shared the name Robert Johnson, who had previously been convicted of plotting a bombing of a Hindu temple. All Robert Johnsons said they have had trouble getting on airplanes.
6. As a crime
In 2011 it emerged that an immigration officer had tried to rid himself of his wife by adding her name to a list of terrorist suspects.
He used his access to security databases to include his wife on a watch list of people banned from boarding flights into Britain because their presence in the country is 'not conducive to the public good'.
As a result the woman was unable for three years to return from Pakistan after travelling to the county to visit family.
The tampering went undetected until the immigration officer was selected for promotion and his wife's name was found on the suspects' list during a vetting inquiry.
The Home Office confirmed that the officer was sacked for gross misconduct.
While most of us have nothing to worry about, social media posts are not automatically discounted when forming a case for someone being added to the list
7. Controversial tweeting
According to the Intercept leak, the guidelines stated that social media posts 'should not be automatically discounted' when forming a case for someone being added to the list.
Agents are required to 'evaluate the credibility of the source, as well as the nature and specificity of the information, and nominate even if that source is uncorroborated', it said.
In addition to this, last month the Huffington Post reported that according to FBI Director James Comey, Twitter has been 'very cooperative' with FBI agents looking into individuals affiliated with the Islamic State and other terrorist organizations that use the social network to organize and inspire people within the U.S. to commit terrorist acts.
The director stated that a lot of terrorist recruits first interact with overseas terrorists on Twitter.
